clinical_study.brief_title: Targeting the Microcirculation in Resuscitation of Patients With Septic Shock
clinical_study.official_title: Targeting the Microcirculation in Resuscitation of Patients With Septic Shock

brief_summary.textblock: Increase in MAP from 65 mm Hg to patients' usual level by fluid improved sublingual microcirculation in early septic shock patients despite EGDT.

detailed_description.textblock: Increase in MAP from 65 mm Hg to patients' usual level by different ways affect sublingual microcirculation in early septic shock patients despite EGDT.

primary_outcome.measure: Sublingual microcirculatory function by SDF of all the patients

arm_group.description: Fluid positive for PLR, then saline performed until MAP to usual level
Fluid responders confirmed by PLR, then NE was adjusted to titrate MAP to usual level
Fluid nonresponders confirmed by PLR, then NE was adjusted to titrate MAP to usual level.

intervention.description: NE infusion to titrate MAP to usual level
Fluid resuscitation to titrate MAP to usual level

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- 1) patients with septic shock for less than 24 hours.
- 2) Fluid resuscitation was performed according to the guideline for treating septic shock to maintain the central venous pressure (CVP) for more than 8 mm Hg and central venous oxygen saturation for more than 70%.
- 3) Patients requiring norepinephrine (NE) to maintain a MAP of 65 mm Hg.
Exclusion Criteria:
- pregnancy, age < 18 years, inability to acquire the usual level of MAP, refusal of consent by the patient or relative, participation in other trials during the last three months, hypertensive patients without hypertension treatment.
